title: Will the 2016 industry-wide average cost of Li-on batteries used in battery-powered electric vehicles be less than $300 per kWh?
preds: (no change but) Not long before Mack reads the entrails.
Because of the "industry-wide average" part of the question.

Tesla claims to pay $190. In the last few years, they have been 25-60% below the average market-price as calculated by the Nature-article (link in question description), although the numbers fluctuate a lot. The 'bandwidth' of the estimates is also quite large.
Not sure how representative developments by Tesla Motors are but willing to take the overall quantitative trend seriously
to see what forecasting is like and i'm involved in field of energy
Moving down per @Raisinville; checking around a bit and will probably go down more.
This is fact now......even adding costs of R&D the unit costs are below $300 kWh.
I assume this refers to the consumer price not the factory price which is well below $300/kWh.

Recent anecdotal evidence on battery technology from Daimler, Nissan and others point to a price below $300. Still find it difficult to find proper data to support this anecdotal evidence so some uncertainty still remains. However on the principle of "no smoke without a fire" I raise my forecast somewhat.

Radically change from my previous forecast. When you are wrong it is best to admit it and change course. I was wrong. Tesla recently announced that their cost for batteries is around $190 per kWh. This is well under $300. Prices were $350 last year. This all points to an industry-wide average cost that will be well below $300.
This year has been with a lot of uncertainity, including political events. There is a trend in reducing free trade that will drive an increase of commodities and other materials
Up again due to strong US$

http://www.autoblog.com/2015/10/08/gm-li-ion-battery-cost-per-kwh-already-down-to-145/
I know that this is only one company, but I think that there's plenty to time for the rest of the pack to catch-up.
Forecast revised down from 14% to 13%. Li-on prices are still (as of 12 October) $350 per kWh and only 20% of the year remains to drop prices $50 or more per kWh. Probably not happening.
Revision of my understanding of the Question
2 Oct 2016 "GM Says Li-ion Battery Cells Down To $145/kWh and Still Falling"  http://www.hybridcars.com/gm-ev-battery-cells-down-to-145kwh-and-still-falling/
DOE is forecasting $200 In next couple years

I don't think it is going to happen. Current industry-wide price is $350 per kWh. It is difficult to find current information on this. I think Tesla, Nissan, and others will have prices below the $300 threshold, but the industry as a whole is not likely to be so fortunate.

I think that some marktet actors have some long term contracts to provide them whit Lithium for a competitive rate. But those contract usually can not be extended if the volume rises. Therefore they may hit the target of under 300 $ / kWh but it wont be sustainable. I have to admit that I've not read the Nature article so I don't know if the price is the average over a longer time period. If not, my judgement is overly pessimistic. If I can get this figured out I'll reevaluate my guess. 
My interpretation of one of the graphs in the paper is that the prices bottom at the level of Tesla (around 300 $). This view is expressed in the cited Nature article. Taking into account the raw material price increase I still doubt the continued steep decline in costs. 
Over all 5 % is really to pessimistic up to 10 %.
Lithium prices go up as demand rises. No new battery technology will see mass production soon. So the prices have no reason to drop. No way the will drop even sharper than the cited 14 % per year.

Given that TSLA, GM and Nissan are pretty much the industry as far as EVs are concerned - GM has stated that it's current status for $/kWh is $145 (see chart in http://www.hybridcars.com/chevy-bolt-production-confirmed-for-2016/) and TSLA has a goal of $100 with the Gigafactory, it seems reasonable to assume that the industry-wide average will drop to below $300 by end of 2016.
I am hazy on the technology--are these the same batteries that burst into glorious flame in your mobile telephone?

If my information is correct and I have made my calculations correct the worlds six biggest producers (representing  above 80 % of production) of Li-on batteries already a weighted average cost of well below 300.

As of 2014, average cost of Li-on batteries industry wide was $410 per kWh, falling at a rate of about 14% per year. Following this trend results in an estimate of $303 per kWh by 2016. However, current reports indicate that both Tesla and GM are already paying less than $200 per kWh, significantly decreasing the $303 estimate.
The incentives and technology is there to lead batteries to a "Moores law" development.
Up 2% to be more above, but still close to the consensus. Still consider this question more of "what does Ouija (tm) predict."
2016 EV sales are not looking good.  This should translate into deflationary prices for Li-on batteries and EVs.  80 to 90%

https://finance.yahoo.com/chart/LIT?ltr=1#%3D%3D
Price of lithium seems to have started to rise again. Not sure of impact of this as many will have hedged supplies well in advance.
" With a cost level of approximately	US$300 per kWh these market-leading actors now set the de facto	current costs for state-of-the-art battery packs."
From paper assuming it is cost of production and not including margin.

Looking at this link it suggests that including margin price will be well above $300. If not including margin it will be below. Does anyone know if margin is included in answer?
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/302664

Because the Minimu Suistenable Price vas around $333 http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy16osti/66086.pdf and thta only Musk's GigaFactory will crash prices down but that will be in 2017 or 2018. Till end of 2016 ctual player will just keep the highest possible margins.

Batteries, unlike computer technology, are not subject to Moore's Law.  There is a limit, chemically, to how much power you can get from a battery of a given size.  Manufacturing techniques can lower cost of the things, so it's possible, but I don't think the cost will automatically drop.
Up 2% to be more above the consensus.
28 June 2016; "Stem CTO: Lithium-Ion Battery Prices Fell 70% in the Last 18 Months" http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/stem-cto-weve-seen-battery-prices-fall-70-in-the-last-18-months

This is a silly forecast.  The ending dollar amount doesn't matter, because it is known that the cost will continue to decline as the technology,  production processes and sales mature.  Limiting the cost to Lithium Ion is also silly, this is a field where there is a lot of interest, new technologies disrupting the market nearly every month and by the time the prediction can come true, the next/best technology will be developed and restarting the price/performance/time cycle.  The better question would be what must be the market penetration of electric vehicles to provide the critical mass demand to meet this dollar target--that should be predictable with pretty high certainty.
Up 3% to stay slightly more above the consensus.

Please see link below for the background on this post
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/258792
It seems that projecting the trend will take us close. So I will say that it will probably happen.

There are two ways (only?) in which this question can be resolved. One is to include the old data from 2007-14 while doing the analysis, and the other way is to base it only on the data sourced from 2014-16 period.
Another battery plant has been scheduled to open - which suggests costs have been coming down.

(no change) Looking again at the "Mack" link above I believe this is what "average" will mean. They will take some number of references which have been sorted to eliminate the same information. Then they will fit the data for 2016. (Since the publications are random it might be anywhere within the year, but suspect it will be skewed toward the end of 2016 or even early 2017.) I believe there will be an "average" for 2016 in the sense that the numbers will be mixed together and be number crunched (with or without weighting â€” I can't see anything about that aspect) but it will NOT compare (or average) the same sources from either the end of 2015 or beginning of 2016. @Enthu
Wit the speed of changes in this arena, I believe that this is very possible and probably will happen.
adjusting to remain just above consensus

Consensus is creeping up on this one. Am comfortable raising to 72% based on my earlier reasoning. But if consensus gets up beyond that, will have to think twice before following. Basically, I will have to take a much more granular approach based on the battery costs of BEV leaders and the non leaders.
Up 5% to be more above consensus. Still not a big fan of forecasting related to what data sets the Mack Inst will use but I think that the industry overall needs to show "progress."

The figure below shows that PHEV battery cost estimates monitored by the US DOE fell from about USD 1,000/kWh in 2008 to USD 268/kWh in 2015, which represents a 73% reduction in seven years (US DOE, 2016)." That works out to 10.43% reduction in cost per year.
https://evannex.com/blogs/news/118365957-international-energy-agency-electric-vehicle-battery-costs-rapidly-declining-tesla-cited-as-leading-the-pack

Resolving this question through the paper's methodology may boil down to whether there are sufficient cost references from parts of the industry that are not the BEV leaders. If you look at the chart, it is clear that the last year studied (2014) has just one such reference compared to three that are from the BEV leaders. This makes sense because BEV leaders are now more in the news and are much more closely studied compared to rest of the industry.

The Mack averages based on historic yearly gains in cost improvements forecasts it to be less than $300. On top of that, increasing demand and competitive fire from Tesla will most likely spur better processes and efficiencies.
i SEE the price of Lithium going down the same path (as an industry) That Iron took last year.
It's already below that number,well below
Tesla is well under the price per kWh, but the industry isn't moving as fast as Tesla
The industry leader reputedly has  internal costs at well under that level. Adding their costs to industry base reduces weighted average

I can't be bothered to digitize the referred plot, but it looks like it's not a proper exponential decay. The halving goes faster in the 2000's than in the 2010's. So no, the decrease has slowed down. Going in 10% below consensus.
Industry at inflection point, expect rapid price differentials

No change but noting discussion regarding reluctance in various parts of the supply chain (mining, for instance) due to hedging on potential for battery technology changes.  Not certain that exists & I don't know of any large changes on verge of commercialization, though battery tech is a perennial area of work.

Supply-demand is increasing as the performance of the battery powered cars now meets industry norms.  Supply growth will drive economies of scale in both R&D and production levels.  There is also an accelerator embedded here as lower costs will translate to lower car costs, and thus allow these cars to be in the purchase price range of larger numbers of buyers.
The cost trend certainly seems to indicate that the $300 barrier, if it's not already broken, will be broken by year-end.

GM announced in October 2015 that their cost per KwH is already at $145. It is however noted that the industry average cost is still around $350. But new models being developed by industry leaders, such as Tesla and GM will drive down the average cost faster.

For the leading manufacturers, the costs seem to be already in $300 range per kWh in 2014 as per Mach article as well as per the below article:
http://arstechnica.com/science/2015/07/electric-vehicle-batteries-are-getting-cheaper-much-faster-than-we-expected/
Going in favour of technology exceeding our expectations but a little concerned about how the answer is to be determined.

Analysts expect lithium prices to rise in the near term because it is difficult to bring enough new supply on line to meet rising demand. However, the cost of lithium material for a long-range electric vehicle is around 3.5% of the total battery cost, and therefore the rising price is unlikely to undermine the adoption of electric vehicles, a Goldman Sachs report says.

The long-term investment of Tesla's Gigafactory will not be reflected in the data this year. The first $5 billion factory should open in 2017. Additionally, shipment of Model 3 only starts by the end of next year. So I believe that we will continue seeing a +- 10% price drop per year from 2014 to 2016 landing the average price of this year slightly above $300 / KWH. Counting on the usual delays of Musk's projects, I assume an accelerated price drop between 2018 en 2020, when Tesla and some new alternatives really weigh in. Tough one!

It looks like the 'Market Leaders' are already under the $300 per kWh level.  However, the industry-wide average may still be a bit over this threshold.  Further research on my part would be required to pin this down.

Supply vs. demand.  Demand continues to be high, keeping the price high.   Production at gigafactory will eventually influence price but until it is 100% online I doubt it's influence on global battery prices will be enough to lower the price that much.
Low oil price is hampering necessary investements

With BYD and Tesla both gaining momentum and manufacturing knowledge via gigafactory construction its very likely costs $/kwh will threaten the $300 mark. Against this is raw material costs of Li carbonate / graphite. Industry projections of cost curves from 2010 and 2011 seem to have underestimated how quickly the costs are coming down. New technology of solid state Li may also impact costs in 2016 but unlikely. Close call - need to understand this more. Placeholder 65% for now due to increasing confidence / knowledge / focus in this area which may cause virtuous improvements.

It's only one data point but Electric Power Research Institute reported in June 2015 that the 2015 average battery pack cost was still forecasted at $400-500/kWh (slide 7)
http://www.eia.gov/conference/2015/pdf/presentations/schoff.pdf
(Important not to confuse cost of a cell with cost of a pack as is pointed out in same slide)
Both consumers as producers of this batteries will gain by such a decrease, so there is a need for these batteries.

The depressed oil price makes EV a hard sell in many parts of the world. However, the low commodity price and large planned manufacturing capacity in China and US will likely drive battery price down.
(no change) "Price" perhaps in the short term is something that is loosely tied to only the business plan(s).
Seems like a reasonable bet that price decline meets $300. Nod to @echodog with a nice analysis. http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/216620
Tesla's giant Nevada factory and subsequent pressures on other manufacturers should drive prices down. The leap from $410 in 2014 and $300 in 2016 seems like a pretty small one.

It seems to me that the technology required to lower the cost of battery packs to below $300 per kilowatt hour is based mostly the economics of scale for production. While there are still advances in battery technology research occurring that can lower the cost of production and increase the energy density of the batteries, much of the cost right now comes down to whether the infrastructure is already in place to produce the batteries themselves.

it went down from about $1000 in 2007 to $450 in 2014, it should continue to go down on a curve so by the end of 2016 it's going to be probably somewhere around $300. these things tend to have a uniformly accelerated motion when it comes to technology.
The increased commercial production of these batteries is pushing the cost down

This article has a better (larger) copy of the Nature article graph: http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2015/04/13/3646004/electric-car-batteries-price/
Still not sure if I should perhaps be on just the other side of 50%

Since the 14% a year is an average, and the cost reduction is logrithmic, can't really see projecting the same rate for 2015 and 2016.  The decline should be less than 14%.  Leaving room for the +/-6%, however, it looks like the official estimate is on the trend line, which may negate the +/- factor.
No one knows how long oil prices will remain this low. BEV Companies are diverting money from R&D towards marketing
Costs are $145 now at GM, the rest of the industry will definitely catch up.

From the paper: "Hence, we believe that the 8% annual cost decline for market-leading actors is more likely to represent the probable future cost improvement for Li-ion battery packs in BEV, whereas the 14% decline for the industry as a whole to some degree represents a correction of earlier, overestimated costs."
It might make TO $300 by the end of 2016, but  the year's average likely higher.
Supply will come in from everywhere and prices will drop
If GM's low cost is a true low cost, other producers should quickly follow.

Given that the question is about "used" rather than purchased it is hard to see how the average could fall so quickly (given the accumulating installed base of vehicles) ..The Mack institute are looking at cost which I believe is a slightly different question.
This depends on some breakthroughs that could happen, but that are hard to foresee.

Up 10% to be closer to consensus. Wondering what "industry-wide" really includes? Would major companies (GM, Tesla, etc.) not want to show significant progress? Ditto for any "startup" competitors that need to scale and get funding.
Current prices would have to fall some way below $300/KWh to give an average 2016 below $300

Wasn't planning on forecasting this one but this article caught my attention:
http://www.computerworld.com/article/3060005/mobile-wireless/scientists-can-now-make-lithium-ion-batteries-last-a-lifetime.html
"She discovered that just by using this gel, she could cycle it hundreds of thousands of times without losing any capacity."
China will use this market to bolster manufacturing as natural resources continue their slump.
Initial forecast. I too expect to regret joining.
Li-ion battery manufacture is tricky and bad batteries pose a fire risk.  No one wants that.
Battery costs are always harder to lower than people think.  So just to start I'm going slightly no.

The cost to manufacture Li-on batteries will decrease, but the cost of electricity is rising in many areas.  The cost in one state may make this possible but in the Midwest or Hawaii, I don't see how this happens over the long term.
GM Says Li-ion Battery Cells Down To $145/kWh and Still Falling
Data spread is huge, staying low without 2015 data

From a brief glance at the Mack chart, it looks like recent estimates have been less noisy than past estimates (only one number seems to have been available in 2007). As noise has dropped, so too has the real rate of cost decline. I'm going to skew low on this, even though some estimates already seem to be below $300/kWh, because I don't think that Mack's estimation procedure will change much.
